Key Match Events: Jamie Smith put on a careful 55 with Jacob Bethell, but when Bethell was caught for 25, Smith was becalmed batting with the enterprising Brydon Carse
Ben Duckett was flummoxed by a slower ball from Aaron Hardie, and Liam Livingstone was caught by a diving Alex Carey with a legside flick first ball
England were 65 for five in the tenth over
Alex Carey and Mitchell Starc leave sloppy England on brink of series defeat
Pre-Game Insights: England had looked in with a good shot at the halfway stage after they dismissed Australia within 45 overs

Phil Salt’s short but eventful innings included three flamed fours, a survived review off Hazlewood, a drop at slip by a lunging Matt Short, before coming to a close as he kissed an edge off Hazlewood to Carey
Harry Brook was off the mark through midwicket with a typically sharp clip to the rope from Starc, to roared appreciation for the local lad
Post-Match Reflections: Brook was phlegmatic afterwards, “We’re an inexperienced team playing against one of the best sides in the world – it’s about patience, we’re only two games in”
Obviously we lost early wickets in the powerplay and that killed us. We took some positive options to put the pressure on but it didn’t come off”

Carey said afterwards. “Not much has to change for everything to change” Carey said afterwards. “They [England] are still a highly skilled bunch of players, but that’s one-day cricket, your momentum is key, at the moment we’ve got the momentum”
Miscellaneous Highlights: England will have that ringing in their ears at Chester-le-Street on Tuesday
The game was a high stakes affair for England, and they were unable to recover from losing early wickets in the powerplay
The crowd was enthusiastic, but eventually emptied as the game was lost
Others: Olly Stone replaced the rested Jofra Archer
Travis Head and Matt Short were the opening partners for Australia
Glenn Maxwell was the excellent Rashid’s 200th ODI wicket
Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne fell cheaply
